args: Sorry for the trouble, everyone,\nbut I need a bit of a favor.
Could you remodel my pirate ship to\nhold an opera stage?
A stage on a ship? Hoo-eee, ma'am!\nNow that's a humdinger of an idea!
But sure, I'll whip ya up a handy little\nstage that can be installed on the deck.
＂Little＂ isn't quite what I had in mind.\nThe audience could only be twenty, thirty\npeople at most in that case.
This is the opera, and I want to entertain\na whole OCEAN of people!
HmmmMMMM... Yes, I think I see.
So essentially you need a way to fit a\nstage on your ship that is larger than the\nvessel itself. Is that accurate?
You picked up on that quick—it seems you\nARE as fine an engineer as advertised.
A good thing, too. With you folks on board,\nmy idea may just work!
Hold, lass. Are ye sayin' you've already\nthought up a way to do this thing?
I have indeed. And the method is...
Gosh, ma'am! That plan's a real head-\nscratcher. Ya really think it can be done?
Aye, she's a fine plan. If we use the rokkan\nstonetech engine, that'll keep 'er movin'\nright trig, so it will.
Which means the rest is all design.\nNow then, how do we take this novel\nendeavor and make it reality?
Ooo, but this is exciting. I love nothing\nbetter than bending physics to my will!
Aye, and me! We'll see this done,\non me honor as a craftswoman!
I'm not much for plans and math and all\nthat, but just tell me what t'build and I'll\nmake sure it's strong as oak.
Leave all your carpentry to me, ma'am!
Well, THIS is filling me with confidence.\nGo, team! Go forth and make me proud!
Hey, is that my lackeys playing?\nSeeing how they started, I must admit\nthey're actually sounding pretty good.
Good choice to gather a bunch of folks\nwho love music. They'll make for a\nsplendid orchestra, methinks!
So that's the stage and the music sorted,\nwhich means next is...
Hey, Lucretia. How go the lessons?
Well, I suppose the song itself is fine,\nbut there is a slight...issue.
I think it might be faster to show you.
Everyone? I'd like you to sing and\nperform as though you're on stage.
Stop. No. Wait.\nDon't fight for my love.
Shiver me timbers, this is TERRIBLE.
The first one's stuttering, the second's\nputting way too much into it, and the\nthird is just reciting things in monotone.
Performance is a difficult thing; you must\nbecome someone you're not.

And playing a completely different person
in terms of status, upbringing, and the like
is exponentially more difficult—especially
for a newcomer.
Oh, hell! I didn't even think about how the\ncharacters in opera are always nobles and\nknights and other proper folk!
They might just be too different for a crew\nof rough-and-tumble pirates.
Yes, I fear that singing an opera will\nprove quite the challenge for them.
It was hard for me when I played the\nprincess, and I used to BE one!
It's just difficult to play a role you can't\nfind a way to empathize with.
...But I think I know a way around that!
When I played the princess, it worked\nbecause I found aspects of her character\nthat I was able to understand.
Basically, I discovered points where\nmy life overlapped with the role.
Which means we'll just have to perform\nan opera where the characters AREN'T\na bunch of highfalutin' nobility!
There's all kinds of opera out there,\nand I'm sure we can find one that works\nif we just look around.
And since no one has more scripts lying\naround than a professional opera singer,\nI know just who to call on!
